security: This document details a clandestine operation to contaminate sugar being shipped from Cuba to the Soviet Union, which could compromise intelligence sources and methods. The document states: "Through a clandestine operation which was not detected and is not traceable, we were able to contaminate 800 of these bags of sugar with a chemical used in the process of denaturing alcohol...This successful contamination will spoil the entire cargo..."
summary: A CIA paper describes a clandestine operation in San Juan, Puerto Rico, to contaminate Cuban sugar being shipped to the Soviet Union with a chemical that would make it unfit for consumption, estimating a loss of $350,000 to $400,000 for the USSR.
summary_one_paragraph: Dated August 29, 1962, this document details a covert CIA operation where 800 bags of Cuban raw sugar, part of a shipment destined for the USSR, were contaminated with a chemical during a temporary off-load in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The operation, conducted without detection, involved a British merchant ship, the STREATHAM HILL, and aimed to render the entire cargo of 80,000 bags unfit for human or animal consumption. The contaminated sugar, valued at $350,000 to $400,000, would have an ineradicable bitter taste due to the chemical used in denaturing alcohol.
title: EXTRACT FROM PAPER SENT GEN. LANSDALE 29 AUGUST '62
